For example, mass, temperature, and energy are scalar quantities. Scalar quantities can be measured using a single number and can be represented using a single value on a number line. The mathematical operations on scalar quantities include addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

On the other hand, a vector quantity is a physical quantity that requires both magnitude and direction to be fully described. For example, displacement, velocity, and force are vector quantities. The length of the vector represents the magnitude of the quantity, while the direction of the vector represents the direction of the quantity. The mathematical operations on vector quantities include addition, subtraction, and multiplication (scalar multiplication and vector multiplication).
